text: and it's time for a review of this new
us girls project bless this mess this is
the newest full-length LP from The
Eclectic mind of singer
multi-instrumentalist songwriter Meg
Remy's U.S girls a project I've been
looking forward to hearing from for
quite a bit now really since 2020's
heavy light which when it was released I
found to be a considerable dip in
quality from her previous in a poem
unlimited which in my opinion is one of
the better Art Pop records of the 2010s
heavy light by comparison though felt
way more choppy and consistent I suppose
a bit meager too though there were some
singles and deep Cuts here and there
that were pretty great so I went into
this record hoping whatever through
heavy light off was just gone over and
done with bless this mess did have some
cool teaser material to start I was
especially enthused to hear how much
disco and old school synth Papa said
medically was kind of guiding the sound
of these songs the run time of this
thing was encouraging too like Hey we're
getting another robust project here but
once I sunk my teeth into the entire
thing I was kind of sad to find that uh
bless this mess is a bit of a mess you
know like with heavy light in pretty
much every U.S girls project so far plus
this mess does have its strong points
first off it starts things with a really
good opener a groovy sweet piece of soft
rock inspired pop with bright Keys
Punchy drums infectious refrains it's
really focused it's enchanting I think
it's a great tone Setter for the record
overall so I was kind of shocked to find
just how jarring the next track was just
space for light with its kind of
dissonant group vocals that sound off
key in a way that I I don't think is
entirely intentional there are some
silly instrumental embellishments and
solo passages on this track too the
track is also derailed by a few awkward
chord changes as well the song is kind
of on unflattering honestly and I don't
think it gets that much better from here
in the tracklist the following screen
face is a track that's all about not
really liking love or trying to force a
love connection through a phone screen a
FaceTime call which I mean is true it
sucks I sympathize with the sentiment
but I don't think the song captures the
torture and emotional tension of the
situation especially with the
instrumental Vibe being such a mismatch
and on top of it the lyrics are just way
too on the nose making mention of this
guy's phone dying but also feeling like
you're dying Michael ralt's guest vocals
on the track don't go over all that well
either and they feel so close in tone to
Megs they fail to play off of her vocal
performance effectively the Futures bet
was a pretty decent teaser for the
record but as I have listened to it more
and more I find the production to be a
bit rougher than I like it's kind of
like an old school piece of synth pop
but with some really just overpowering
flabby guitar passages that drown a lot
of the mix out I do think the chorus of
the song hits with the Bliss of a great
radio pop hit though and I suppose the
lyrics are pretty interesting
acknowledging the chaos of the world we
live in but responding to it with a let
go and let the chips fall where they may
kind of attitude and I suppose having
faith in the fact that humanity and
Society will continue on in some way
shape or form and saying hey this is
just life y'all so typically now was
another teaser I liked from the project
that actually hasn't lost its luster in
the track list it's a colorful and bold
piece of disco and soul fusion with
fiery background vocals Phil Collins
size drum fills the angular lead
Melodies on the chorus that sync up with
the synthesizers are really nice and I
like the lyrics of the track as well
reflecting on one's desire to escape our
modern technological dystopia also
wanting to get out of the city it's all
about a struggle to find some peace in
this world and put yourself in a place
that you're more comfortable in next we
have the centerpiece piece of the record
the title track of the record which is a
spotlit piano ballad with a super solid
chord progression but I don't know if
it's the emotional showstopper Meg
intended it to be in terms of
performance like I could think back to
dozens of quality sappy ballads from the
80s and 70s that emotionally hit a lot
harder than this even with some
commendable lyrics on the song about
accepting yourself as a flawed person I
suppose I just enjoy the sentiment of
the song a lot more than the way it's
pulled off tux was another standout for
me in the tracklist though it is a
cheeky bold and flirty disco cut that
sees Meg singing from the standpoint of
a tuxedo who I guess is singing about a
man or a person who once owned this tux
and wore it proudly instead of just kind
of stashing it away in a plastic bag in
the closet Meg sings now you're too
embarrassed to wear me around the house
it's catchy it's funny it's playful
lines like a costume is that how you see
me stand out with the most amazing
amount of Camp honestly it's great I
can't get enough of it but then this is
followed by R.I.P Roy G Biv which
um I nominate for maybe the worst song
on this thing like given the title I
think some can kind of see where the
song is going uh in terms of color and I
do like the lyrics attempt to humanize
the concept of color in a rainbow but
the stiff pianos on this track combined
with the refrains of red and orange and
yellow and green I feel like I'm
listening to a bad Public Access
children's song about colors from here
we go into a pretty unimpressive last
leg on the record St James way I found
to be an okay ballad that gets lost in
the sparkling and glamorous
instrumentation it's covered in then
pump is a quirky nocturnal Funk track
with a super expressive bass line and
the lyrics of this song are essentially
about using a breast pump to feed your
child which is honestly a pretty unique
song topic given the front cover here I
think I went into this thing expecting
at least some material on this record to
be about motherhood and for sure this
track is but I feel like it has maybe a
few different potential topics
collapsing onto each other at once the
most real feeling on this track that I
think is worth addressing is just the
sense for Meg that this whole motherhood
thing in terms of feeding her kids and
obviously the way her kids were
delivered she felt kind of thrown into
it not warned of the pros the cons the
dangers the the obstacles that she would
have to overcome in the process the lack
of Readiness some people have for such a
life change can feel like being thrown
to the Wolves but I think a lot of that
emotion and uh potential commentary gets
lost in the need to depict uh the sound
and I guess just mechanics of a breast
pump on the track with refrains of how
does the milk make it to your mouth pump
pump
yeah there are some elements of the
track I can certainly commend in terms
of its creativity its willingness to try
something vastly different from what a
lot of other songwriters out there right
now are doing frankly I think it's cool
that Meg has taken upon herself to
normalize motherhood in music spaces
such as the one that she inhabits and
commenting on the trials and
tribulations of this experience is a
good thing but the assembly and
execution of this track does leave a lot
to be desired as does the closing track
which I think again is another very on
the nose moment where I think Meg kind
of belabers uh the the this attempt to
explain I guess the topical focus of
this record in a way which I just don't
think was all that necessary and once
more just sounds a lot like some uh
forgettable PBS music programming so I'm
kind of torn on this record honestly it
had some highlights it had some low
lights uh but even some of the weirdest
moments I had to admit were pretty out
there and creative and at least somewhat
unique I'm not really sure what else to
add about this record other than like
with heavy light I hope the next one is
a lot better I'm feeling a strong five
to a light six on this one transition
